newsitem.title: USA: U.S. rig count rises in May 23 week.
newsitem.headline: U.S. rig count rises in May 23 week.

text.p: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States stood at 948 as of May 23, up 31 from the prior week and 173 above the year-ago total of 775, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Friday.
The number of rigs drilling on land rose by 32 to 803, while rigs working offshore was unchanged at 120. The number of rigs active in inland waters fell by one to 25.
Among the individual states, the biggest changes occurred in Texas, which was up by 13. Colorado and New Mexico saw a drop of two and three rigs, respectively.
The Gulf of Mexico rig count rose one to 115.
A total of 387 rigs were exploring for crude oil, up 19 from last week. The number of rigs searching for gas rose by 12 to 557, while the number of miscellaneous drilling projects remained at four.
There were 196 rigs drilling directionally, 74 drilling horizontally and 678 drilling vertically.
In Canada, the number of working rigs rose by 31 to 280, versus 142 a year ago.
The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.
Separately, there were 170 rigs under contract in the U.S. Gulf as of May 23, down one from the period ending May 16, Offshore Data Services said Friday.
The utilization rate for rigs working in the Gulf, based on a total fleet of 179, was unchanged at 95.0 percent.
The number of working rigs in the European/Mediterranean area was up one at 106 rigs under contract out of a total fleet of 107, a utilization rate also unchanged at 99.1 pct.
The worldwide rig count was unchanged at 577 out of a total fleet of 605, with a utilization rate down from 95.7 percent at 95.4 percent.
